question: Which cranial nerve's fibers are myelinated by oligodendrocytes?
exp: The fibers of the optic nerve (CN II) are myelinated by oligodendrocytes. This is an impoant distinction from the Other cranial nerves ( myelinated by Schwann cells) because the optic nerve is considered a tract of the central nervous system

question: Inferior olivary nucleus is present in
exp: The inferior olivary nucleus, a cerebellar relay nucleus, is the most prominent nucleus in the lateral medulla. Coordinate signals from the spinal cord to the cerebellum to regulate motor coordination and learning. fig:- crossection at the level of medulla(upper pa)
opb: Midbrain, at level of superior colliculus
opc: Midbrain, at level of inferior colliculus

question: A chronic alcoholic presents with truncal instability and an uncoordinated gait. An MRI confirms alcoholic degeneration of the cerebellar vermis. Which of the following cells is most notably destroyed in this patient?
exp: Alcohol is directly toxic to the cerebellum, causing degeneration primarily of the anterior superior vermis. This is due to either shrinkage or atrophy of Purkinje cells. Chronic alcoholism results in a risk of significant loss of Purkinje cells. This is worsened by associated vitamin B1 deficiency, resulting from both a poor diet and a direct toxic effect on vitamin B1 metabolism. Golgi(2) cell exes an inhibitory influence on the synapse between the mossy fiber and the granule cell, within the cerebellar glomerulus. Basket(1) cells provide direct inhibitory influences on the Purkinje cells. In the cerebellar glomerulus, the mossy fiber afferents synapse with the granule cell (4). After this first processing stage, the granule cell conveys this afferent information to the Purkinje cell and the Golgi cell (through excitatory parallel fibers).

question: In which pa of the brain is the cerebral aqueduct is found?
exp: Cerebral aqueduct of sylvius is found in the Midbrain (mesencephalon); it connects the third ventricle to the fouh ventricle. Midbrain is derived from mesencephalon.

question: The efferent limb of the gag reflex is?
exp: The gag reflex involves a brisk and brief elevation of the soft palate and bilateral contraction of pharyngeal muscles evoked by touching the posterior pharyngeal wall The vagus nerve (CN X) provides the efferent limb of the gag reflex (muscles of the soft palate). The glossopharyngeal nerve provides the afferent limb of the gag reflex.

question: Findings of trigeminal nerve injury include -
exp: Shining a bright light into one eye causes reflex closure of both eyes the blink reflex ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve. Pupillary dilation and ptosis is seen in 3rd nerve injury In trigeminal nerve injury their is loss of jaw reflex which is mediated by mandibular nerve
opb: Loss of blinking reflex of eye

question: The efferent limb of the corneal reflex Is -
exp: The corneal reflex, also known as the blink reflex, is an involuntary blinking of the eyelids elicited by stimulation of the cornea (such as by touching or by a foreign body) Corneal reflex-The reflex is mediated by: the nasociliary branch of the ophthalmic branch (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) sensing the stimulus on the cornea only (afferent fiber). the temporal and zygomatic branches of the facial nerve (CN VII) initiating the motor response (efferent fiber). The facial nerve (CN VII) provides the efferent limb of the corneal reflex (orbicularis oculi muscle) fig:- digramatic representaion of corneal reflex pathway

question: "Abducent nucleus" is present in
exp: The abducent nucleus (CN VI) is located in the dorsomedial tegmentum of the pons. fig:-crossection atthe level of lower pons
opa: Midbrain, at level of inferior colliculus

question: The cranial nerve emerging between pyramid and olive is?
exp: Nerves emerging b/w pyramid and olive is - CN XII Nerves emerging posterior to olive - CN IX, X & XI. At ponto-medullary junction: Most medial nerve - CN VI. Middle - CN VII (motor & sensory) Most lateral nerve - CN VIII CN Emergence 1 Comes from nose, synapse in olfactory bulb. 2 Comes from orbit 3 Cerebral peduncular fossa of midbrain 4 Dorsal aspect of midbrain 5 Pons. 6, 7, 8 Pontomedullary junction 9, 10, 11, 12 Medulla oblongata

question: "Nucleus ambiguus" is present at
exp: The nucleus ambiguus is found in the lateral medulla; it gives rise to the SVE (Special visceral efferent fibers ) components of cranial nerves IX and X. fig:- crossection at the level of medulla(upper pa)
opb: Midbrain, at level of superior colliculus
opc: Midbrain, at level of inferior colliculus

question: Cerebellar nucleus involved in saccadic eye movement:-
exp: Cerebellar nuclei function Dentate working with lateral pa Co-ordinate movement of joint Fastigial working with central vermis Saccadic eye movement. Interposed nuclei (emboliform & globose) working with para vermal area Feedback mechanism from joints to have proper co- ordination of joint.

question: "Red nucleus" is present at
exp: The red nucleus is diagnostic of midbrain division at the level of the superior colliculus; it lies between the occulomotor nucleus (CN III) and the substantia nigra. fig:- crossection at the level of Superior colliculus Midbrain
opb: Midbrain, at level of superior colliculus
opc: Midbrain, at level of inferior colliculus

question: Which one of the cranial nerves exits the brainstem from the posterior aspect?
exp: Trochlear nerve (CN IV)is the only cranial nerve to exit the brainstem from the dorsal/ posterior aspect.

question: Which thalamic nucleus projects to the striatum?
exp: The striatum (caudate nucleus & putamen) receives thalamic input from centromedian nucleus. centromedian nucleus- largest of the intralaminar nuclei.
